finding: The study identified a previously uncharacterized disulfide bond in the receptor for several cytokines, including interleukin-4, interleukin-7, and interleukin-11, which is involved in the function of the receptor.
The study found that mild reduction of this disulfide bond inhibited proliferation of an IL-2-dependent T cell clone and the activation of the STAT-5 pathway.

The study demonstrated that a disulfide bond in the receptor for several cytokines, including IL-4, IL-7, and IL-11, is at the interface with the cytokine and is involved in the function of the receptor.
The study showed that reducing the disulfide bond in the receptor for several cytokines, including IL-4, IL-7, and IL-11, inhibited the activation of the STAT-5 pathway.
The study revealed that reducing the disulfide bond in the receptor for several cytokines, including IL-4, IL-7, and IL-11, inhibited the proliferation of an IL-2-dependent T cell clone.
